        "premises": "None of the students who currently work in the library are from the computer science department. \nAll of the students with part-time jobs offered by the university currently work in the library. \nAll of the students who are taking the database course are from the computer science department. \nAll of the students taking a class with Professor David are taking the database course. \nAll students working in the lab are taking a class with Professor David.\nJames is a student working in the lab. \nJames doesn't work in the lab or have a part-time job offered by the university.",
        "conclusions": "James has a part-time job offered by the university.",
        "rationale": "Step 1: From the premise \"None of the students who currently work in the library are from the computer science department,\" we know that no student working in the library is from the computer science department.\nStep 2: The premise \"All of the students with part-time jobs offered by the university currently work in the library\" means that if a student has a part-time job offered by the university, they must be working in the library.\nStep 3: Since James is working in the lab (Premise \"James is a student working in the lab\"), and all students working in the lab are taking a class with Professor David (Premise \"All students working in the lab are taking a class with Professor David\"), James must be taking a class with Professor David.\nStep 4: The premise \"All of the students taking a class with Professor David are taking the database course\" means that if James is taking a class with Professor David, then he must be taking the database course.\nStep 5: The premise \"All of the students who are taking the database course are from the computer science department\" means that if James is taking the database course, he must be from the computer science department.\nStep 6: Combining steps 3, 4, and 5, we conclude that if James is working in the lab, he must be taking the database course, which means he must be from the computer science department.\nStep 7: From step 1, since no student working in the library is from the computer science department, and James is not working in the library (Premise \"James doesn't work in the lab or have a part-time job offered by the university\"), he cannot have a part-time job offered by the university.\nStep 8: Since James does not have a part-time job offered by the university, the statement \"James has a part-time job offered by the university\" is false.\nTherefore, the answer is (B).\n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</Answer>",
        "label": "False",
        "predict": "False",

Hence, there is no guaranteed contradiction in being a sophist while remaining morally perfect\u2014He could be the sort of sophist who does not reason.\nStep 6: Because the theistic God cannot be both morally perfect and a philosopher, the statement \u201cThe theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher\u201d is false.\nTherefore, the answer is (B). \n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</Answer>\n</EXAMPLE 2>\n\n<EXAMPLE 3>\n<Premises>\nWilliam Dickinson was a British politician who sat in the House of Commons William Dickinson attended Westminster school for high school and then the University of Edinburgh. \nThe University of Edinburgh is a university located in the United Kingdom. \nWilliam Dickinson supported the Portland Whigs. \nPeople who supported the Portland Whigs did not get a seat in the Parliament.\n</Premises>\n<Conclusion>\nWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university.\n</Conclusion>\n<Question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain?     {
        "premises": "None of the students who currently work in the library are from the computer science department. \nAll of the students with part-time jobs offered by the university currently work in the library. \nAll of the students who are taking the database course are from the computer science department. \nAll of the students taking a class with Professor David are taking the database course. \nAll students working in the lab are taking a class with Professor David.\nJames is a student working in the lab. \nJames doesn't work in the lab or have a part-time job offered by the university.",
        "conclusions": "James either takes the database course or has a part-time job offered by the university.",
        "rationale": "Step 1: From the premise \"None of the students who currently work in the library are from the computer science department,\" we know that no students from the computer science department are working in the library.\n\nStep 2: From the premise \"All of the students with part-time jobs offered by the university currently work in the library,\" we know that all students with part-time jobs from the university work in the library.\n\nStep 3: From the premise \"All of the students who are taking the database course are from the computer science department,\" we know that all students taking the database course are from the computer science department.\n\nStep 4: From the premise \"All of the students taking a class with Professor David are taking the database course,\" we know that all students taking a class with Professor David are taking the database course and thus are from the computer science department.\n\nStep 5: From the premise \"All students working in the lab are taking a class with Professor David,\" we know that all students working in the lab are taking a class with Professor David and thus are taking the database course and are from the computer science department.\n\nStep 6: From the premise \"James is a student working in the lab,\" we know that James is taking a class with Professor David, taking the database course, and is from the computer science department.\n\nStep 7: From the premise \"James doesn't work in the lab or have a part-time job offered by the university,\" we know that James does not have a part-time job from the university.\n\nStep 8: Combining steps 6 and 7, we know that James is taking the database course and does not have a part-time job from the university.\n\nStep 9: The conclusion states that \"James either takes the database course or has a part-time job offered by the university.\" Since we have established that James is taking the database course and does not have a part-time job from the university, the conclusion is true because the disjunction (either/or) condition is satisfied by the fact that James is taking the database course.\n\nTherefore, the answer is (A).\n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (A).\n</Answer>",
        "label": "True",
        "predict": "True",
        "user_prompt": [
            {
                "role": "user",
                "content": "You will be provided with an input text that consists of Premises and Conclusions. Your task is to determine whether the conclusion is True, False, or Uncertain based solely on the premises. To do this, generate natural language reasoning steps that lead to your final answer.\n\nThe input text is structured as follows:\n- The premises are enclosed within <Premises> and </Premises>.\n- The conclusion is enclosed within <Conclusion> and </Conclusion>.\n- The question is enclosed within <Question> and </Question>.\n- The answer options are provided within <Options> and </Options>.\n\nYour output should include:\n1. A reasoning section enclosed within <Reasoning> and </Reasoning> that explains your thought process.\n2. The final answer enclosed within <Answer> and </Answer>.\n\n\n\nBelow are three examples that demonstrate the desired reasoning style:\n\n<EXAMPLE 1>\n<Premises>\nPeter Parker is either a superhero or a civilian.\nThe Hulk is a destroyer.\nThe Hulk wakes up when he is angry.\nIf the Hulk wakes up, then he will break a bridge.\nThor is a god.\nThor will break a bridge when he is happy.\nA god is not a destroyer.\nPeter Parker wears a uniform when he is a superhero.\nPeter Parker is not a civilian if a destroyer is breaking a bridge.\nIf Thor is happy, the Hulk is angry.\n</Premises>\n<Conclusion>\nIf Thor is happy, then Peter Parker wears a uniform.\n</Conclusion>\n<Question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker wears a uniform.\n</Question> \n<Options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</Options>\n<Reasoning>\nStep 1: given premises \"If Thor is happy, the Hulk is angry.\" and \"The Hulk wakes up when he is angry.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then hulk wakes up.\"\nStep 2: given premise \"If the Hulk wakes up, then he will break a bridge.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then hulk wakes up.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then hulk will break a bridge.\"\nStep 3: given premise \"The Hulk is a destroyer.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then hulk will break a bridge.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then a destroyer will break a bridge.\"\nStep 4: given premise \"Peter Parker is not a civilian if a destroyer is breaking a bridge.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then a destroyer will break a bridge.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker is not a civilian\"\nStep 5: given premise \"Peter Parker is either a superhero or a civilian.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker is not a civilian\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker is a superhero.\"\nStep 6: given premise \"Peter Parker wears a uniform when he is a superhero.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker is a superhero.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker wears a uniform\"\nTherefore, the answer is (A).\n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (A).\n</Answer>\n</EXAMPLE 1>\n\n<EXAMPLE 2>\n<Premises>\nAll philosophers reason.\nSome sophists reason.\nAll who can reason can distinguish truth from falsehood.\nNobody who can distinguish truth from falsehood is morally perfect.\nThe theistic God is morally perfect.\nThe theistic God is a sophist.\n</Premises>\n<Conclusion>\nThe theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher.\n</Conclusion>\n<Question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? The theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher.\n</Question>\n<Options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</Options>\n<Reasoning>\nStep 1: From the premise \u201cAll philosophers reason,\u201d we know that if someone is a philosopher, then that individual necessarily has the ability to reason.\nStep 2: From the premise \u201cAll who can reason can distinguish truth from falsehood,\u201d we conclude that if someone reasons, they will also distinguish truth from falsehood.\nStep 3: The premise \u201cNobody who can distinguish truth from falsehood is morally perfect\u201d implies that if one does indeed distinguish truth from falsehood, they cannot be morally perfect.\nStep 4: Since the theistic God is stated to be \u201cmorally perfect,\u201d if the theistic God were a philosopher, He would have to reason (by Step 1), which would lead to distinguishing truth from falsehood (by Step 2), thereby making Him not morally perfect (by Step 3). This contradicts the premise that the theistic God is morally perfect, so He cannot be a philosopher.\nStep 5: Separately, the premise says \u201cThe theistic God is a sophist.\u201d We also know \u201cSome sophists reason,\u201d which does not imply that every sophist necessarily reasons. Hence, there is no guaranteed contradiction in being a sophist while remaining morally perfect\u2014He could be the sort of sophist who does not reason.\nStep 6: Because the theistic God cannot be both morally perfect and a philosopher, the statement \u201cThe theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher\u201d is false.\nTherefore, the answer is (B). \n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</Answer>\n</EXAMPLE 2>\n\n<EXAMPLE 3>\n<Premises>\nWilliam Dickinson was a British politician who sat in the House of Commons William Dickinson attended Westminster school for high school and then the University of Edinburgh. \nThe University of Edinburgh is a university located in the United Kingdom. \nWilliam Dickinson supported the Portland Whigs. \nPeople who supported the Portland Whigs did not get a seat in the Parliament.\n</Premises>\n<Conclusion>\nWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university.\n</Conclusion>\n<Question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? William Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university.\n</Question> \n<Options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</Options>\n<Reasoning>\nStep 1: The premise states that \u201cWilliam Dickinson attended Westminster school for high school and then the University of Edinburgh.\u201d We also know that \u201cThe University of Edinburgh is a university located in the United Kingdom,\u201d so we can confirm that William Dickinson\u2019s university education took place in the UK.\nStep 2: However, the premise does not explicitly state that Westminster School is located in the UK. Although many readers might know from general knowledge that Westminster School is in London, the text itself does not provide this information.\nStep 3: Since the conclusion claims that \u201cWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university,\u201d we can confirm the university part is in the UK but have insufficient information about the high school (Westminster School).\nStep 4: Because the premise does not definitively place Westminster School in the UK, it is impossible to conclude with certainty that both schools he attended were in the UK. We therefore lack enough textual evidence to deem the conclusion strictly true.\nStep 5: There is also no premise suggesting that Westminster School is outside of the UK, so we cannot declare the conclusion false. The conclusion could be true in reality, but the text does not confirm it.\nStep 6: As a result, the statement \u201cWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university\u201d remains unverified by the given premises and is thus uncertain.\nTherefore, the answer is (C). \n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (C).\n</Answer>\n</EXAMPLE 3>\n\n\n\nThe following is the problem you need to solve.\n\n<Premises>\nNone of the students who currently work in the library are from the computer science department. \nAll of the students with part-time jobs offered by the university currently work in the library. \nAll of the students who are taking the database course are from the computer science department. \nAll of the students taking a class with Professor David are taking the database course. \nAll students working in the lab are taking a class with Professor David.\nJames is a student working in the lab. \nJames doesn't work in the lab or have a part-time job offered by the university.\n</Premises>\n<Conclusion>\nJames either takes the database course or has a part-time job offered by the university.\n</Conclusion>\n<Question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? James either takes the database course or has a part-time job offered by the university.\n</Question>\n<Options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</Options>\n<Reasoning>\n"

This is because the only way to be from the computer science department is to be working in the library or having a part-time job, and James is excluded from these conditions.\nStep 6: Given that James is not from the computer science department and the premise \"All of the students who are taking the database course are from the computer science department,\" we can conclude that James cannot be taking the database course.\nTherefore, the statement \"James takes the database course\" is false.\n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</Answer>",

        "premises": "If George likes music, he wants to compose.\nIf George has access to a program, he can compose.\nIf George can compose and wants to compose, he will compose.",
        "conclusions": "If George will not compose, George can not compose.",
        "rationale": "Step 1: Analyze the premises provided. The first premise states that if George likes music, he wants to compose. The second premise states that if George has access to a program, he can compose. The third premise states that if George can compose and wants to compose, he will compose.\n\nStep 2: Consider the conclusion: \"If George will not compose, George can not compose.\" To validate this, we need to see if the premises logically lead to this conclusion.\n\nStep 3: From the third premise, \"If George can compose and wants to compose, he will compose,\" we can infer that for George to compose, two conditions must be met: he must be able to compose and he must want to compose.\n\nStep 4: The second premise, \"If George has access to a program, he can compose,\" tells us that having access to a program is a condition for George to be able to compose. However, this does not provide information about his desire to compose.\n\nStep 5: The first premise, \"If George likes music, he wants to compose,\" suggests that liking music is a condition for George to want to compose. Again, this does not directly relate to his ability to compose, but rather his desire.\n\nStep 6: Now, let's consider the scenario where George will not compose. For George not to compose, at least one of the two necessary conditions (being able to compose and wanting to compose) must not be met. If George can compose but does not want to, he will not compose. If George does not have access to a program, he cannot compose. If George does not like music, he does not want to compose.\n\nStep 7: However, the conclusion \"If George will not compose, George can not compose\" suggests that the inability to compose is the only reason for not composing. This is not necessarily true based on the premises. George can also choose not to compose even if he can and wants to, for example, if he decides that he does not want to compose at that moment.\n\nStep 8: Therefore, the conclusion does not logically follow from the premises because there could be other reasons for George not composing, such as a lack of desire or a conscious decision, beyond just the inability to compose.\n\nTherefore, the answer is (C).</Answer>",

                "content": "You will be provided with an input text that consists of Premises and Conclusions. Your task is to determine whether the conclusion is True, False, or Uncertain based solely on the premises. To do this, generate natural language reasoning steps that lead to your final answer.\n\nThe input text is structured as follows:\n- The premises are enclosed within <Premises> and </Premises>.\n- The conclusion is enclosed within <Conclusion> and </Conclusion>.\n- The question is enclosed within <Question> and </Question>.\n- The answer options are provided within <Options> and </Options>.\n\nYour output should include:\n1. A reasoning section enclosed within <Reasoning> and </Reasoning> that explains your thought process.\n2. The final answer enclosed within <Answer> and </Answer>.\n\n\n\nBelow are three examples that demonstrate the desired reasoning style:\n\n<EXAMPLE 1>\n<Premises>\nPeter Parker is either a superhero or a civilian.\nThe Hulk is a destroyer.\nThe Hulk wakes up when he is angry.\nIf the Hulk wakes up, then he will break a bridge.\nThor is a god.\nThor will break a bridge when he is happy.\nA god is not a destroyer.\nPeter Parker wears a uniform when he is a superhero.\nPeter Parker is not a civilian if a destroyer is breaking a bridge.\nIf Thor is happy, the Hulk is angry.\n</Premises>\n<Conclusion>\nIf Thor is happy, then Peter Parker wears a uniform.\n</Conclusion>\n<Question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker wears a uniform.\n</Question> \n<Options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</Options>\n<Reasoning>\nStep 1: given premises \"If Thor is happy, the Hulk is angry.\" and \"The Hulk wakes up when he is angry.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then hulk wakes up.\"\nStep 2: given premise \"If the Hulk wakes up, then he will break a bridge.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then hulk wakes up.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then hulk will break a bridge.\"\nStep 3: given premise \"The Hulk is a destroyer.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then hulk will break a bridge.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then a destroyer will break a bridge.\"\nStep 4: given premise \"Peter Parker is not a civilian if a destroyer is breaking a bridge.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then a destroyer will break a bridge.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker is not a civilian\"\nStep 5: given premise \"Peter Parker is either a superhero or a civilian.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker is not a civilian\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker is a superhero.\"\nStep 6: given premise \"Peter Parker wears a uniform when he is a superhero.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker is a superhero.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker wears a uniform\"\nTherefore, the answer is (A).\n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (A).\n</Answer>\n</EXAMPLE 1>\n\n<EXAMPLE 2>\n<Premises>\nAll philosophers reason.\nSome sophists reason.\nAll who can reason can distinguish truth from falsehood.\nNobody who can distinguish truth from falsehood is morally perfect.\nThe theistic God is morally perfect.\nThe theistic God is a sophist.\n</Premises>\n<Conclusion>\nThe theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher.\n</Conclusion>\n<Question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? The theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher.\n</Question>\n<Options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</Options>\n<Reasoning>\nStep 1: From the premise \u201cAll philosophers reason,\u201d we know that if someone is a philosopher, then that individual necessarily has the ability to reason.\nStep 2: From the premise \u201cAll who can reason can distinguish truth from falsehood,\u201d we conclude that if someone reasons, they will also distinguish truth from falsehood.\nStep 3: The premise \u201cNobody who can distinguish truth from falsehood is morally perfect\u201d implies that if one does indeed distinguish truth from falsehood, they cannot be morally perfect.\nStep 4: Since the theistic God is stated to be \u201cmorally perfect,\u201d if the theistic God were a philosopher, He would have to reason (by Step 1), which would lead to distinguishing truth from falsehood (by Step 2), thereby making Him not morally perfect (by Step 3). This contradicts the premise that the theistic God is morally perfect, so He cannot be a philosopher.\nStep 5: Separately, the premise says \u201cThe theistic God is a sophist.\u201d We also know \u201cSome sophists reason,\u201d which does not imply that every sophist necessarily reasons. Hence, there is no guaranteed contradiction in being a sophist while remaining morally perfect\u2014He could be the sort of sophist who does not reason.\nStep 6: Because the theistic God cannot be both morally perfect and a philosopher, the statement \u201cThe theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher\u201d is false.\nTherefore, the answer is (B). \n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</Answer>\n</EXAMPLE 2>\n\n<EXAMPLE 3>\n<Premises>\nWilliam Dickinson was a British politician who sat in the House of Commons William Dickinson attended Westminster school for high school and then the University of Edinburgh. \nThe University of Edinburgh is a university located in the United Kingdom. \nWilliam Dickinson supported the Portland Whigs. \nPeople who supported the Portland Whigs did not get a seat in the Parliament.\n</Premises>\n<Conclusion>\nWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university.\n</Conclusion>\n<Question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? William Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university.\n</Question> \n<Options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</Options>\n<Reasoning>\nStep 1: The premise states that \u201cWilliam Dickinson attended Westminster school for high school and then the University of Edinburgh.\u201d We also know that \u201cThe University of Edinburgh is a university located in the United Kingdom,\u201d so we can confirm that William Dickinson\u2019s university education took place in the UK.\nStep 2: However, the premise does not explicitly state that Westminster School is located in the UK. Although many readers might know from general knowledge that Westminster School is in London, the text itself does not provide this information.\nStep 3: Since the conclusion claims that \u201cWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university,\u201d we can confirm the university part is in the UK but have insufficient information about the high school (Westminster School).\nStep 4: Because the premise does not definitively place Westminster School in the UK, it is impossible to conclude with certainty that both schools he attended were in the UK. We therefore lack enough textual evidence to deem the conclusion strictly true.\nStep 5: There is also no premise suggesting that Westminster School is outside of the UK, so we cannot declare the conclusion false. The conclusion could be true in reality, but the text does not confirm it.\nStep 6: As a result, the statement \u201cWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university\u201d remains unverified by the given premises and is thus uncertain.\nTherefore, the answer is (C). \n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (C).\n</Answer>\n</EXAMPLE 3>\n\n\n\nThe following is the problem you need to solve.\n\n<Premises>\nIf George likes music, he wants to compose.\nIf George has access to a program, he can compose.\nIf George can compose and wants to compose, he will compose.\n</Premises>\n<Conclusion>\nIf George will not compose, George can not compose.\n</Conclusion>\n<Question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? If George will not compose, George can not compose.\n</Question>\n<Options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</Options>\n<Reasoning>\n"
            }
        ]
    },

        "premises": "A hawk never swims. \nSome birds are hawks.",
        "conclusions": "All birds swim.",
        "rationale": "Step 1: From the premise \"A hawk never swims,\" we know that at least one bird (the hawk) does not swim.\nStep 2: The premise \"Some birds are hawks\" tells us that there is an overlap between the category of birds and the category of hawks, but it does not provide information about the swimming habits of all birds.\nStep 3: Since we know that there is at least one bird (the hawk) that does not swim, it directly contradicts the statement \"All birds swim.\"\nStep 4: The fact that some birds are hawks does not provide any information about the swimming habits of birds that are not hawks. We cannot infer anything about the swimming behavior of other birds based on the given premises.\nStep 5: Given that we have a specific counterexample (the hawk) that does not swim, the statement \"All birds swim\" cannot be true.\nTherefore, the answer is (B).\n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</Answer>",

        "conclusions": "Breaking Bad is on Monday at 8 pm.",
        "rationale": "Step 1: Analyze the premises given:\n- Some show airing at 8 pm on Monday gives out roses on TV.\n- If a show gives out roses on TV, then the show is an episode of The Bachelor.\n- The Bachelor portrays the lives of real people.\n- All shows portraying the lives of real people are reality TV shows.\n- Breaking Bad is a show.\n- Breaking Bad is not a reality TV show.\n\nStep 2: From the premises, we know that the show airing at 8 pm on Monday is an episode of The Bachelor (since it gives out roses on TV). The Bachelor is a reality TV show (since it portrays the lives of real people and all such shows are reality TV shows).\n\nStep 3: However, we are also told that Breaking Bad is not a reality TV show. Since the show airing at 8 pm on Monday is an episode of The Bachelor, and The Bachelor is a reality TV show, it follows that the show airing at 8 pm on Monday cannot be Breaking Bad.\n\nStep 4: The conclusion we need to evaluate is \"Breaking Bad is on Monday at 8 pm.\" Since we have established that the show airing at 8 pm on Monday is an episode of The Bachelor and not Breaking Bad, we can conclude that Breaking Bad is not on Monday at 8 pm.\n\nTherefore, the statement \"Breaking Bad is on Monday at 8 pm\" is false.\n\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</Answer>",

        "premises": "Some show airing at 8 pm on Monday gives out roses on TV.\nIf a show gives out roses on TV, then the show is an episode of The Bachelor.\nThe Bachelor portrays the lives of real people.\nAll shows portraying the lives of real people are reality TV shows.\nBreaking Bad is a show.\nBreaking Bad is not a reality TV show.",
        "conclusions": "Breaking Bad is a TV show in which roses are given out on Monday at 8 pm.",
        "rationale": "Step 1: From the premise \"Some show airing at 8 pm on Monday gives out roses on TV,\" we know there is at least one show that fits this description, but we do not know which specific show it is.\n\nStep 2: From the premise \"If a show gives out roses on TV, then the show is an episode of The Bachelor,\" we can infer that any show that gives out roses on TV must be an episode of The Bachelor.\n\nStep 3: From the premise \"The Bachelor portrays the lives of real people,\" we know that The Bachelor is a show that portrays the lives of real people.\n\nStep 4: From the premise \"All shows portraying the lives of real people are reality TV shows,\" we can deduce that The Bachelor is a reality TV show.\n\nStep 5: We are given that \"Breaking Bad is a show,\" which is a factual statement about Breaking Bad.\n\nStep 6: We are also given that \"Breaking Bad is not a reality TV show,\" which contradicts the conclusion that Breaking Bad could be a show in which roses are given out on Monday at 8 pm, as such a show would have to be an episode of The Bachelor, which is a reality TV show.\n\nStep 7: Since Breaking Bad is explicitly stated to not be a reality TV show, and the only show that gives out roses on TV is an episode of The Bachelor (which is a reality TV show), it is impossible for Breaking Bad to be a show that gives out roses on Monday at 8 pm.\n\nTherefore, the statement \"Breaking Bad is a TV show in which roses are given out on Monday at 8 pm\" is false.\n\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</Answer>",

A reasoning section enclosed within <Reasoning> and </Reasoning> that explains your thought process.\n2. The final answer enclosed within <Answer> and </Answer>.\n\n\n\nBelow are three examples that demonstrate the desired reasoning style:\n\n<EXAMPLE 1>\n<Premises>\nPeter Parker is either a superhero or a civilian.\nThe Hulk is a destroyer.\nThe Hulk wakes up when he is angry.\nIf the Hulk wakes up, then he will break a bridge.\nThor is a god.\nThor will break a bridge when he is happy.\nA god is not a destroyer.\nPeter Parker wears a uniform when he is a superhero.\nPeter Parker is not a civilian if a destroyer is breaking a bridge.\nIf Thor is happy, the Hulk is angry.\n</Premises>\n<Conclusion>\nIf Thor is happy, then Peter Parker wears a uniform.\n</Conclusion>\n<Question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker wears a uniform.\n</Question> \n<Options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</Options>\n<Reasoning>\nStep 1: given premises \"If Thor is happy, the Hulk is angry.\" and \"The Hulk wakes up when he is angry.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then hulk wakes up.\"\nStep 2: given premise \"If the Hulk wakes up, then he will break a bridge.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then hulk wakes up.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then hulk will break a bridge.\"\nStep 3: given premise \"The Hulk is a destroyer.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then hulk will break a bridge.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then a destroyer will break a bridge.\"\nStep 4: given premise \"Peter Parker is not a civilian if a destroyer is breaking a bridge.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then a destroyer will break a bridge.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker is not a civilian\"\nStep 5: given premise \"Peter Parker is either a superhero or a civilian.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker is not a civilian\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker is a superhero.\"\nStep 6: given premise \"Peter Parker wears a uniform when he is a superhero.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker is a superhero.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker wears a uniform\"\nTherefore, the answer is (A).\n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (A).\n</Answer>\n</EXAMPLE 1>\n\n<EXAMPLE 2>\n<Premises>\nAll philosophers reason.\nSome sophists reason.\nAll who can reason can distinguish truth from falsehood.\nNobody who can distinguish truth from falsehood is morally perfect.\nThe theistic God is morally perfect.\nThe theistic God is a sophist.\n</Premises>\n<Conclusion>\nThe theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher.\n</Conclusion>\n<Question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? The theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher.\n</Question>\n<Options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</Options>\n<Reasoning>\nStep 1: From the premise \u201cAll philosophers reason,\u201d we know that if someone is a philosopher, then that individual necessarily has the ability to reason.\nStep 2: From the premise \u201cAll who can reason can distinguish truth from falsehood,\u201d we conclude that if someone reasons, they will also distinguish truth from falsehood.\nStep 3: The premise \u201cNobody who can distinguish truth from falsehood is morally perfect\u201d implies that if one does indeed distinguish truth from falsehood, they cannot be morally perfect.\nStep 4: Since the theistic God is stated to be \u201cmorally perfect,\u201d if the theistic God were a philosopher, He would have to reason (by Step 1), which would lead to distinguishing truth from falsehood (by Step 2), thereby making Him not morally perfect (by Step 3). This contradicts the premise that the theistic God is morally perfect, so He cannot be a philosopher.\nStep 5: Separately, the premise says \u201cThe theistic God is a sophist.\u201d We also know \u201cSome sophists reason,\u201d which does not imply that every sophist necessarily reasons. Hence, there is no guaranteed contradiction in being a sophist while remaining morally perfect\u2014He could be the sort of sophist who does not reason.\nStep 6: Because the theistic God cannot be both morally perfect and a philosopher, the statement \u201cThe theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher\u201d is false.\nTherefore, the answer is (B). \n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</Answer>\n</EXAMPLE 2>\n\n<EXAMPLE 3>\n<Premises>\nWilliam Dickinson was a British politician who sat in the House of Commons William Dickinson attended Westminster school for high school and then the University of Edinburgh. \nThe University of Edinburgh is a university located in the United Kingdom. \nWilliam Dickinson supported the Portland Whigs. \nPeople who supported the Portland Whigs did not get a seat in the Parliament.\n</Premises>\n<Conclusion>\nWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university.\n</Conclusion>\n<Question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? William Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university.\n</Question> \n<Options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</Options>\n<Reasoning>\nStep 1: The premise states that \u201cWilliam Dickinson attended Westminster school for high school and then the University of Edinburgh.\u201d We also know that \u201cThe University of Edinburgh is a university located in the United Kingdom,\u201d so we can confirm that William Dickinson\u2019s university education took place in the UK.\nStep 2: However, the premise does not explicitly state that Westminster School is located in the UK. Although many readers might know from general knowledge that Westminster School is in London, the text itself does not provide this information.\nStep 3: Since the conclusion claims that \u201cWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university,\u201d we can confirm the university part is in the UK but have insufficient information about the high school (Westminster School).\nStep 4: Because the premise does not definitively place Westminster School in the UK, it is impossible to conclude with certainty that both schools he attended were in the UK. We therefore lack enough textual evidence to deem the conclusion strictly true.\nStep 5: There is also no premise suggesting that Westminster School is outside of the UK, so we cannot declare the conclusion false. The conclusion could be true in reality, but the text does not confirm it.\nStep 6: As a result, the statement \u201cWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university\u201d remains unverified by the given premises and is thus uncertain.\nTherefore, the answer is (C). \n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (C).\n</Answer>\n</EXAMPLE 3>\n\n\n\nThe following is the problem you need to solve.\n\n<Premises>\nSome show airing at 8 pm on Monday gives out roses on TV.\nIf a show gives out roses on TV, then the show is an episode of The Bachelor.\nThe Bachelor portrays the lives of real people.\nAll shows portraying the lives of real people are reality TV shows.\nBreaking Bad is a show.\nBreaking Bad is not a reality TV show.\n</Premises>\n<Conclusion>\nBreaking Bad is a TV show in which roses are given out on Monday at 8 pm.\n</Conclusion>\n<Question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? Breaking Bad is a TV show in which roses are given out on Monday at 8 pm.\n</Question>\n<Options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</Options>\n<Reasoning>\n"
            }
        ]

        "premises": "Some show airing at 8 pm on Monday gives out roses on TV.\nIf a show gives out roses on TV, then the show is an episode of The Bachelor.\nThe Bachelor portrays the lives of real people.\nAll shows portraying the lives of real people are reality TV shows.\nBreaking Bad is a show.\nBreaking Bad is not a reality TV show.",
        "conclusions": "If roses are given out during Breaking Bad, then it is on Monday at 8 pm.",
        "rationale": "Step 1: From the premise \"Some show airing at 8 pm on Monday gives out roses on TV,\" we understand that there is at least one show that airs at 8 pm on Monday and gives out roses on TV. However, this does not specify that this show is unique or that it is The Bachelor.\n\nStep 2: From the premise \"If a show gives out roses on TV, then the show is an episode of The Bachelor,\" we can deduce that any show that gives out roses on TV must be an episode of The Bachelor. This means that the show mentioned in Step 1, which gives out roses on TV, is an episode of The Bachelor.\n\nStep 3: From the premise \"The Bachelor portrays the lives of real people,\" we know that the show that gives out roses on TV (which is an episode of The Bachelor) portrays the lives of real people.\n\nStep 4: From the premise \"All shows portraying the lives of real people are reality TV shows,\" we can infer that the episode of The Bachelor which gives out roses on TV is a reality TV show.\n\nStep 5: The premise \"Breaking Bad is a show\" is given, but does not provide any direct information about it giving out roses or its schedule.\n\nStep 6: The premise \"Breaking Bad is not a reality TV show\" directly states that Breaking Bad is not a reality TV show. Since the show that gives out roses on TV is a reality TV show (from Step 4), it cannot be Breaking Bad.\n\nStep 7: Given that the show giving out roses on TV is an episode of The Bachelor (from Step 2) and not Breaking Bad (from Step 6), it is impossible for roses to be given out during Breaking Bad. Therefore, the statement \"If roses are given out during Breaking Bad, then it is on Monday at 8 pm\" is based on an impossible scenario.\n\nTherefore, the statement is false because the antecedent (roses are given out during Breaking Bad) is impossible given the premises.\n\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</Answer>",

This means that Heinrich Schmidt was part of both the Prussian State Parliament and the Nazi Reichstag.\n\nStep 3: Given that Heinrich Schmidt is a German politician (from Step 1) and he was part of both the Prussian State Parliament and the Nazi Reichstag (from Step 2), we can conclude that Heinrich Schmidt fits the criteria stated in the conclusion.\n\nStep 4: The conclusion states that \"Some German politician was part of both the Prussian State Parliament and the Nazi Reichstag.\" Since Heinrich Schmidt, who is a German politician, was part of both the Prussian State Parliament and the Nazi Reichstag, the conclusion is supported by the premises.\n\nTherefore, the conclusion is true based on the information provided in the premises.\n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (A).\n</Answer>",

A reasoning section enclosed within <Reasoning> and </Reasoning> that explains your thought process.\n2. The final answer enclosed within <Answer> and </Answer>.\n\n\n\nBelow are three examples that demonstrate the desired reasoning style:\n\n<EXAMPLE 1>\n<Premises>\nPeter Parker is either a superhero or a civilian.\nThe Hulk is a destroyer.\nThe Hulk wakes up when he is angry.\nIf the Hulk wakes up, then he will break a bridge.\nThor is a god.\nThor will break a bridge when he is happy.\nA god is not a destroyer.\nPeter Parker wears a uniform when he is a superhero.\nPeter Parker is not a civilian if a destroyer is breaking a bridge.\nIf Thor is happy, the Hulk is angry.\n</Premises>\n<Conclusion>\nIf Thor is happy, then Peter Parker wears a uniform.\n</Conclusion>\n<Question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker wears a uniform.\n</Question> \n<Options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</Options>\n<Reasoning>\nStep 1: given premises \"If Thor is happy, the Hulk is angry.\" and \"The Hulk wakes up when he is angry.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then hulk wakes up.\"\nStep 2: given premise \"If the Hulk wakes up, then he will break a bridge.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then hulk wakes up.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then hulk will break a bridge.\"\nStep 3: given premise \"The Hulk is a destroyer.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then hulk will break a bridge.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then a destroyer will break a bridge.\"\nStep 4: given premise \"Peter Parker is not a civilian if a destroyer is breaking a bridge.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then a destroyer will break a bridge.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker is not a civilian\"\nStep 5: given premise \"Peter Parker is either a superhero or a civilian.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker is not a civilian\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker is a superhero.\"\nStep 6: given premise \"Peter Parker wears a uniform when he is a superhero.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker is a superhero.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker wears a uniform\"\nTherefore, the answer is (A).\n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (A).\n</Answer>\n</EXAMPLE 1>\n\n<EXAMPLE 2>\n<Premises>\nAll philosophers reason.\nSome sophists reason.\nAll who can reason can distinguish truth from falsehood.\nNobody who can distinguish truth from falsehood is morally perfect.\nThe theistic God is morally perfect.\nThe theistic God is a sophist.\n</Premises>\n<Conclusion>\nThe theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher.\n</Conclusion>\n<Question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? The theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher.\n</Question>\n<Options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</Options>\n<Reasoning>\nStep 1: From the premise \u201cAll philosophers reason,\u201d we know that if someone is a philosopher, then that individual necessarily has the ability to reason.\nStep 2: From the premise \u201cAll who can reason can distinguish truth from falsehood,\u201d we conclude that if someone reasons, they will also distinguish truth from falsehood.\nStep 3: The premise \u201cNobody who can distinguish truth from falsehood is morally perfect\u201d implies that if one does indeed distinguish truth from falsehood, they cannot be morally perfect.\nStep 4: Since the theistic God is stated to be \u201cmorally perfect,\u201d if the theistic God were a philosopher, He would have to reason (by Step 1), which would lead to distinguishing truth from falsehood (by Step 2), thereby making Him not morally perfect (by Step 3). This contradicts the premise that the theistic God is morally perfect, so He cannot be a philosopher.\nStep 5: Separately, the premise says \u201cThe theistic God is a sophist.\u201d We also know \u201cSome sophists reason,\u201d which does not imply that every sophist necessarily reasons. Hence, there is no guaranteed contradiction in being a sophist while remaining morally perfect\u2014He could be the sort of sophist who does not reason.\nStep 6: Because the theistic God cannot be both morally perfect and a philosopher, the statement \u201cThe theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher\u201d is false.\nTherefore, the answer is (B). \n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</Answer>\n</EXAMPLE 2>\n\n<EXAMPLE 3>\n<Premises>\nWilliam Dickinson was a British politician who sat in the House of Commons William Dickinson attended Westminster school for high school and then the University of Edinburgh. \nThe University of Edinburgh is a university located in the United Kingdom. \nWilliam Dickinson supported the Portland Whigs. \nPeople who supported the Portland Whigs did not get a seat in the Parliament.\n</Premises>\n<Conclusion>\nWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university.\n</Conclusion>\n<Question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? William Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university.\n</Question> \n<Options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</Options>\n<Reasoning>\nStep 1: The premise states that \u201cWilliam Dickinson attended Westminster school for high school and then the University of Edinburgh.\u201d We also know that \u201cThe University of Edinburgh is a university located in the United Kingdom,\u201d so we can confirm that William Dickinson\u2019s university education took place in the UK.\nStep 2: However, the premise does not explicitly state that Westminster School is located in the UK. Although many readers might know from general knowledge that Westminster School is in London, the text itself does not provide this information.\nStep 3: Since the conclusion claims that \u201cWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university,\u201d we can confirm the university part is in the UK but have insufficient information about the high school (Westminster School).\nStep 4: Because the premise does not definitively place Westminster School in the UK, it is impossible to conclude with certainty that both schools he attended were in the UK. We therefore lack enough textual evidence to deem the conclusion strictly true.\nStep 5: There is also no premise suggesting that Westminster School is outside of the UK, so we cannot declare the conclusion false. The conclusion could be true in reality, but the text does not confirm it.\nStep 6: As a result, the statement \u201cWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university\u201d remains unverified by the given premises and is thus uncertain.\nTherefore, the answer is (C). \n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (C).\n</Answer>\n</EXAMPLE 3>\n\n\n\nThe following is the problem you need to solve.\n\n<Premises>\nHeinrich Schmidt was a German politician. \nHeinrich Schmidt was also a member of the Prussian State Parliament and the Nazi Reichstag.\n</Premises>\n<Conclusion>\nSome German politician was part of both the Prussian State Parliament and the Nazi Reichstag.\n</Conclusion>\n<Question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? Some German politician was part of both the Prussian State Parliament and the Nazi Reichstag.\n</Question>\n<Options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</Options>\n<Reasoning>\n"
            }
        ]

        "conclusions": "No politicians are part of the Nazi Reichstag.",

A reasoning section enclosed within <Reasoning> and </Reasoning> that explains your thought process.\n2.         "rationale": "Step 1: From the premise \"If something is a deadly disease, then it comes with a low survival rate,\" we know that deadly diseases are associated with low survival rates. \nStep 2: The premise \"Severe cancers are deadly diseases\" tells us that severe cancers are a subset of deadly diseases.\nStep 3: The premise \"Bile duct cancer is a severe form of cancer\" indicates that bile duct cancer is a specific type of severe cancer.\nStep 4: The premise \"All Cholangiocarcinoma is bile duct cancer\" means that Cholangiocarcinoma is a type of bile duct cancer.\nStep 5: The premise \"Colorectal cancer is not both a bile duct cancer and with a low survival rate\" tells us that colorectal cancer is not a bile duct cancer and does not have a low survival rate. Since bile duct cancers are deadly diseases and come with a low survival rate, and colorectal cancer does not have a low survival rate, it cannot be a bile duct cancer.\nStep 6: Since colorectal cancer is not a bile duct cancer and bile duct cancers are severe cancers (from Step 2), we cannot conclude that colorectal cancer is a severe cancer. The information provided does not establish a direct link between colorectal cancer and the category of severe cancers.\nStep 7: Therefore, based on the given premises, we do not have enough information to confirm that colorectal cancer is a kind of severe cancer.\n\nTherefore, the answer is (C).\n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (C).\n</Answer>",

    {
        "premises": "If something is a deadly disease, then it comes with a low survival rate. \nSevere cancers are deadly diseases.\nBile duct cancer is a severe form cancer. \nAll Cholangiocarcinoma is bile duct cancer.\nMild flu comes with a low survival rate.\nColorectal cancer is not both a bile duct cancer and with a low survival rate.",
        "conclusions": "If colorectal cancer is a kind of bile duct cancer or a form of Cholangiocarcinoma, then colorectal cancer is a kind of bile duct cancer and a kind of mild flu.",
        "rationale": "Step 1: From the premise \"Severe cancers are deadly diseases,\" and \"Bile duct cancer is a severe form of cancer,\" we can infer that \"Bile duct cancer is a deadly disease.\"\nStep 2: From the premise \"All Cholangiocarcinoma is bile duct cancer,\" we know that \"Cholangiocarcinoma is a type of bile duct cancer.\"\nStep 3: The premise \"Colorectal cancer is not both a bile duct cancer and with a low survival rate\" means that if colorectal cancer is a bile duct cancer, it cannot have a low survival rate. However, this does not provide direct information about whether colorectal cancer is a bile duct cancer or not.\nStep 4: The premise \"If something is a deadly disease, then it comes with a low survival rate\" does not directly apply to colorectal cancer, as the latter premise is about deadly diseases in general and does not specify the survival rate of colorectal cancer.\nStep 5: The premise \"Mild flu comes with a low survival rate\" is irrelevant to the properties of colorectal cancer as it discusses a different condition.\nStep 6: The premise \"Colorectal cancer is not both a bile duct cancer and with a low survival rate\" implies that colorectal cancer cannot be a bile duct cancer if it has a low survival rate, but it does not provide information about whether colorectal cancer can be a bile duct cancer if it does not have a low survival rate.\nStep 7: The conclusion states that if colorectal cancer is a kind of bile duct cancer or a form of Cholangiocarcinoma, then it must be both a kind of bile duct cancer and a kind of mild flu. This conclusion is based on a combination of the premises that colorectal cancer cannot be a bile duct cancer with a low survival rate and the irrelevant mild flu premise.\nStep 8: Given the information from the premises, we cannot definitively conclude that colorectal cancer must be a mild flu if it is a bile duct cancer or a form of Cholangiocarcinoma. The premises do not provide enough information to support the claim that colorectal cancer must be a mild flu if it is a bile duct cancer.\nTherefore, the statement is uncertain based on the given premises.\n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (C).\n</Answer>",

A reasoning section enclosed within <Reasoning> and </Reasoning> that explains your thought process.\n2. The final answer enclosed within <Answer> and </Answer>.\n\n\n\nBelow are three examples that demonstrate the desired reasoning style:\n\n<EXAMPLE 1>\n<Premises>\nPeter Parker is either a superhero or a civilian.\nThe Hulk is a destroyer.\nThe Hulk wakes up when he is angry.\nIf the Hulk wakes up, then he will break a bridge.\nThor is a god.\nThor will break a bridge when he is happy.\nA god is not a destroyer.\nPeter Parker wears a uniform when he is a superhero.\nPeter Parker is not a civilian if a destroyer is breaking a bridge.\nIf Thor is happy, the Hulk is angry.\n</Premises>\n<Conclusion>\nIf Thor is happy, then Peter Parker wears a uniform.\n</Conclusion>\n<Question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker wears a uniform.\n</Question> \n<Options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</Options>\n<Reasoning>\nStep 1: given premises \"If Thor is happy, the Hulk is angry.\" and \"The Hulk wakes up when he is angry.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then hulk wakes up.\"\nStep 2: given premise \"If the Hulk wakes up, then he will break a bridge.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then hulk wakes up.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then hulk will break a bridge.\"\nStep 3: given premise \"The Hulk is a destroyer.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then hulk will break a bridge.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then a destroyer will break a bridge.\"\nStep 4: given premise \"Peter Parker is not a civilian if a destroyer is breaking a bridge.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then a destroyer will break a bridge.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker is not a civilian\"\nStep 5: given premise \"Peter Parker is either a superhero or a civilian.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker is not a civilian\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker is a superhero.\"\nStep 6: given premise \"Peter Parker wears a uniform when he is a superhero.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker is a superhero.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker wears a uniform\"\nTherefore, the answer is (A).\n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (A).\n</Answer>\n</EXAMPLE 1>\n\n<EXAMPLE 2>\n<Premises>\nAll philosophers reason.\nSome sophists reason.\nAll who can reason can distinguish truth from falsehood.\nNobody who can distinguish truth from falsehood is morally perfect.\nThe theistic God is morally perfect.\nThe theistic God is a sophist.\n</Premises>\n<Conclusion>\nThe theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher.\n</Conclusion>\n<Question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? The theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher.\n</Question>\n<Options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</Options>\n<Reasoning>\nStep 1: From the premise \u201cAll philosophers reason,\u201d we know that if someone is a philosopher, then that individual necessarily has the ability to reason.\nStep 2: From the premise \u201cAll who can reason can distinguish truth from falsehood,\u201d we conclude that if someone reasons, they will also distinguish truth from falsehood.\nStep 3: The premise \u201cNobody who can distinguish truth from falsehood is morally perfect\u201d implies that if one does indeed distinguish truth from falsehood, they cannot be morally perfect.\nStep 4: Since the theistic God is stated to be \u201cmorally perfect,\u201d if the theistic God were a philosopher, He would have to reason (by Step 1), which would lead to distinguishing truth from falsehood (by Step 2), thereby making Him not morally perfect (by Step 3). This contradicts the premise that the theistic God is morally perfect, so He cannot be a philosopher.\nStep 5: Separately, the premise says \u201cThe theistic God is a sophist.\u201d We also know \u201cSome sophists reason,\u201d which does not imply that every sophist necessarily reasons. Hence, there is no guaranteed contradiction in being a sophist while remaining morally perfect\u2014He could be the sort of sophist who does not reason.\nStep 6: Because the theistic God cannot be both morally perfect and a philosopher, the statement \u201cThe theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher\u201d is false.\nTherefore, the answer is (B). \n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</Answer>\n</EXAMPLE 2>\n\n<EXAMPLE 3>\n<Premises>\nWilliam Dickinson was a British politician who sat in the House of Commons William Dickinson attended Westminster school for high school and then the University of Edinburgh. \nThe University of Edinburgh is a university located in the United Kingdom. \nWilliam Dickinson supported the Portland Whigs. \nPeople who supported the Portland Whigs did not get a seat in the Parliament.\n</Premises>\n<Conclusion>\nWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university.\n</Conclusion>\n<Question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? William Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university.\n</Question> \n<Options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</Options>\n<Reasoning>\nStep 1: The premise states that \u201cWilliam Dickinson attended Westminster school for high school and then the University of Edinburgh.\u201d We also know that \u201cThe University of Edinburgh is a university located in the United Kingdom,\u201d so we can confirm that William Dickinson\u2019s university education took place in the UK.\nStep 2: However, the premise does not explicitly state that Westminster School is located in the UK. Although many readers might know from general knowledge that Westminster School is in London, the text itself does not provide this information.\nStep 3: Since the conclusion claims that \u201cWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university,\u201d we can confirm the university part is in the UK but have insufficient information about the high school (Westminster School).\nStep 4: Because the premise does not definitively place Westminster School in the UK, it is impossible to conclude with certainty that both schools he attended were in the UK. We therefore lack enough textual evidence to deem the conclusion strictly true.\nStep 5: There is also no premise suggesting that Westminster School is outside of the UK, so we cannot declare the conclusion false. The conclusion could be true in reality, but the text does not confirm it.\nStep 6: As a result, the statement \u201cWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university\u201d remains unverified by the given premises and is thus uncertain.\nTherefore, the answer is (C). \n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (C).\n</Answer>\n</EXAMPLE 3>\n\n\n\nThe following is the problem you need to solve.\n\n<Premises>\nIf something is a deadly disease, then it comes with a low survival rate. \nSevere cancers are deadly diseases.\nBile duct cancer is a severe form cancer. \nAll Cholangiocarcinoma is bile duct cancer.\nMild flu comes with a low survival rate.\nColorectal cancer is not both a bile duct cancer and with a low survival rate.\n</Premises>\n<Conclusion>\nIf colorectal cancer is a kind of bile duct cancer or a form of Cholangiocarcinoma, then colorectal cancer is a kind of bile duct cancer and a kind of mild flu.\n</Conclusion>\n<Question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? If colorectal cancer is a kind of bile duct cancer or a form of Cholangiocarcinoma, then colorectal cancer is a kind of bile duct cancer and a kind of mild flu.\n</Question>\n<Options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</Options>\n<Reasoning>\n"
            }

        "premises": "If something is a deadly disease, then it comes with a low survival rate. \nSevere cancers are deadly diseases.\nBile duct cancer is a severe form cancer. \nAll Cholangiocarcinoma is bile duct cancer.\nMild flu comes with a low survival rate.\nColorectal cancer is not both a bile duct cancer and with a low survival rate.",
        "conclusions": "Colorectal cancer is a form of Cholangiocarcinoma and it is a kind of mild flu or a kind of bile duct cancer, or all of the above.",
        "rationale": "Step 1: Analyze the given premises to understand the relationships between the different types of cancers and their characteristics.\n- If something is a deadly disease, then it comes with a low survival rate.\n- Severe cancers are deadly diseases.\n- Bile duct cancer is a severe form of cancer.\n- All Cholangiocarcinoma is bile duct cancer.\n- Mild flu comes with a low survival rate.\n- Colorectal cancer is not both a bile duct cancer and with a low survival rate.\n\nStep 2: Deduce the characteristics of each type of cancer.\n- Since bile duct cancer is a severe form of cancer, it is a deadly disease and comes with a low survival rate.\n- Cholangiocarcinoma is a type of bile duct cancer, so it also comes with a low survival rate.\n- Colorectal cancer is not both a bile duct cancer and with a low survival rate, which implies that colorectal cancer is not a bile duct cancer and does not have a low survival rate. This is a contradiction because if it were a bile duct cancer, it would have to have a low survival rate, but it does not.\n\nStep 3: Evaluate the conclusion based on the premises.\n- The statement claims that Colorectal cancer is a form of Cholangiocarcinoma, which is false because Cholangiocarcinoma is a type of bile duct cancer, and Colorectal cancer is not a bile duct cancer.\n- The statement also claims that Colorectal cancer is a kind of mild flu, which is false because the premises do not suggest that Colorectal cancer is a mild flu; in fact, it is not a bile duct cancer and does not have a low survival rate, which is characteristic of a mild flu.\n- The statement also claims that Colorectal cancer is a kind of bile duct cancer, which is false based on the premises.\n\nStep 4: Since all parts of the conclusion are contradicted by the premises, the statement is false.\n\nTherefore, the answer is (B).\n\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</Answer>",

        "conclusions": "Taylor eats salads regularly.",
        "rationale": "Step 1: From the premise \"All people who grew up in health-conscious childhood homes eat salads regularly,\" and the statement \"Taylor either grew up in a health-conscious childhood home and disregards her physical well-being, or she did neither,\" we need to consider both possibilities for Taylor:\n   - If Taylor grew up in a health-conscious childhood home and disregards her physical well-being, then the second part of the premise (disregarding physical well-being) would apply.\n   - If Taylor did neither, then she did not grow up in a health-conscious childhood home.\n\nStep 2: From the premise \"All people who eat salads regularly are very conscious about their health and eating habits,\" and \"All people who disregard their physical well-being are not very conscious about their health and eating habits,\" if Taylor disregards her physical well-being, she cannot be very conscious about her health and eating habits. But this again contradicts the statement that she either grew up in a health-conscious home and disregards her physical well-being, or she did neither.\n\nStep 5: Given the premises and the statement about Taylor, there is no scenario where Taylor can be definitively said to eat salads regularly.     {
        "premises": "All people who eat salads regularly are very conscious about their health and eating habits.\nAll people who grew up in health-conscious childhood homes eat salads regularly.\nAll people who fulfill their daily nutritional intakes grew up in health-conscious childhood homes.\nAll people who disregard their physical well-being are not very conscious about their health and eating habits.\nIf people visit the gym at least once a day, then they always fulfill their daily nutritional intakes.\nTaylor either grew up in a health-conscious childhood home and disregard her physical well-being, or she did neither.",
        "conclusions": "Taylor visits the gym at least once a day.",
        "rationale": "Step 1: Analyze the premise \"Taylor either grew up in a health-conscious childhood home and disregard her physical well-being, or she did neither.\" This means Taylor cannot be in a health-conscious home and disregard her physical well-being at the same time. She must be in one of two scenarios:\n   - Scenario 1: Taylor grew up in a health-conscious childhood home and disregards her physical well-being.\n   - Scenario 2: Taylor did not grow up in a health-conscious childhood home and does not disregard her physical well-being.\n\nStep 2: Consider Scenario 1. If Taylor grew up in a health-conscious childhood home, then according to the premise \"All people who grew up in health-conscious childhood homes eat salads regularly,\" Taylor eats salads regularly. Since she eats salads regularly, she is \"very conscious about her health and eating habits.\" But the premise \"All people who disregard their physical well-being are not very conscious about their health and eating habits\" states that someone who disregards their physical well-being cannot be very conscious about their health and eating habits. Therefore, Scenario 1 is not possible because Taylor cannot both eat salads regularly (which means she is very conscious about her health and eating habits) and disregard her physical well-being.\n\nStep 3: Since Scenario 1 is not possible, Scenario 2 must be true. In Scenario 2, Taylor did not grow up in a health-conscious childhood home and does not disregard her physical well-being. If Taylor did not grow up in a health-conscious childhood home, then according to the premise \"All people who grew up in health-conscious childhood homes eat salads regularly,\" Taylor does not eat salads regularly. If Taylor does not eat salads regularly, she is not \"very conscious about her health and eating habits.\"\n\nStep 4: Since Taylor does not eat salads regularly, she is not very conscious about her health and eating habits. According to the premise \"All people who eat salads regularly are very conscious about their health and eating habits,\" this is consistent with Taylor not eating salads regularly.\n\nStep 5: Now, consider the premise \"If people visit the gym at least once a day, then they always fulfill their daily nutritional intakes.\" We need to determine if Taylor always fulfills her daily nutritional intakes to see if she visits the gym at least once a day. However, the premises do not provide any direct information about Taylor's daily nutritional intake or her gym visits.\n\nStep 6: Since we have established that Taylor did not grow up in a health-conscious childhood home and does not disregard her physical well-being, we cannot definitively conclude whether she fulfills her daily nutritional intakes or visits the gym at least once a day. The given premises do not provide enough information to determine if Taylor visits the gym at least once a day.\n\nTherefore, the statement \"Taylor visits the gym at least once a day\" is uncertain based on the given premises.\n\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (C).\n</Answer>",
        "label": "False",
        "predict": "Uncertain",
        "user_prompt": [
            {
                "role": "user",
                "content": "You will be provided with an input text that consists of Premises and Conclusions. Your task is to determine whether the conclusion is True, False, or Uncertain based solely on the premises. To do this, generate natural language reasoning steps that lead to your final answer.\n\nThe input text is structured as follows:\n- The premises are enclosed within <Premises> and </Premises>.\n- The conclusion is enclosed within <Conclusion> and </Conclusion>.\n- The question is enclosed within <Question> and </Question>.\n- The answer options are provided within <Options> and </Options>.\n\nYour output should include:\n1. A reasoning section enclosed within <Reasoning> and </Reasoning> that explains your thought process.\n2. The final answer enclosed within <Answer> and </Answer>.\n\n\n\nBelow are three examples that demonstrate the desired reasoning style:\n\n<EXAMPLE 1>\n<Premises>\nPeter Parker is either a superhero or a civilian.\nThe Hulk is a destroyer.\nThe Hulk wakes up when he is angry.\nIf the Hulk wakes up, then he will break a bridge.\nThor is a god.\nThor will break a bridge when he is happy.\nA god is not a destroyer.\nPeter Parker wears a uniform when he is a superhero.\nPeter Parker is not a civilian if a destroyer is breaking a bridge.\nIf Thor is happy, the Hulk is angry.\n</Premises>\n<Conclusion>\nIf Thor is happy, then Peter Parker wears a uniform.\n</Conclusion>\n<Question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker wears a uniform.\n</Question> \n<Options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</Options>\n<Reasoning>\nStep 1: given premises \"If Thor is happy, the Hulk is angry.\" and \"The Hulk wakes up when he is angry.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then hulk wakes up.\"\nStep 2: given premise \"If the Hulk wakes up, then he will break a bridge.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then hulk wakes up.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then hulk will break a bridge.\"\nStep 3: given premise \"The Hulk is a destroyer.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then hulk will break a bridge.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then a destroyer will break a bridge.\"\nStep 4: given premise \"Peter Parker is not a civilian if a destroyer is breaking a bridge.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then a destroyer will break a bridge.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker is not a civilian\"\nStep 5: given premise \"Peter Parker is either a superhero or a civilian.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker is not a civilian\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker is a superhero.\"\nStep 6: given premise \"Peter Parker wears a uniform when he is a superhero.\" and derivation \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker is a superhero.\", we can know \"If Thor is happy, then Peter Parker wears a uniform\"\nTherefore, the answer is (A).\n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (A).\n</Answer>\n</EXAMPLE 1>\n\n<EXAMPLE 2>\n<Premises>\nAll philosophers reason.\nSome sophists reason.\nAll who can reason can distinguish truth from falsehood.\nNobody who can distinguish truth from falsehood is morally perfect.\nThe theistic God is morally perfect.\nThe theistic God is a sophist.\n</Premises>\n<Conclusion>\nThe theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher.\n</Conclusion>\n<Question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? The theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher.\n</Question>\n<Options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</Options>\n<Reasoning>\nStep 1: From the premise \u201cAll philosophers reason,\u201d we know that if someone is a philosopher, then that individual necessarily has the ability to reason.\nStep 2: From the premise \u201cAll who can reason can distinguish truth from falsehood,\u201d we conclude that if someone reasons, they will also distinguish truth from falsehood.\nStep 3: The premise \u201cNobody who can distinguish truth from falsehood is morally perfect\u201d implies that if one does indeed distinguish truth from falsehood, they cannot be morally perfect.\nStep 4: Since the theistic God is stated to be \u201cmorally perfect,\u201d if the theistic God were a philosopher, He would have to reason (by Step 1), which would lead to distinguishing truth from falsehood (by Step 2), thereby making Him not morally perfect (by Step 3). This contradicts the premise that the theistic God is morally perfect, so He cannot be a philosopher.\nStep 5: Separately, the premise says \u201cThe theistic God is a sophist.\u201d We also know \u201cSome sophists reason,\u201d which does not imply that every sophist necessarily reasons. Hence, there is no guaranteed contradiction in being a sophist while remaining morally perfect\u2014He could be the sort of sophist who does not reason.\nStep 6: Because the theistic God cannot be both morally perfect and a philosopher, the statement \u201cThe theistic God is a sophist and a philosopher\u201d is false.\nTherefore, the answer is (B). \n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (B).\n</Answer>\n</EXAMPLE 2>\n\n<EXAMPLE 3>\n<Premises>\nWilliam Dickinson was a British politician who sat in the House of Commons William Dickinson attended Westminster school for high school and then the University of Edinburgh. \nThe University of Edinburgh is a university located in the United Kingdom. \nWilliam Dickinson supported the Portland Whigs. \nPeople who supported the Portland Whigs did not get a seat in the Parliament.\n</Premises>\n<Conclusion>\nWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university.\n</Conclusion>\n<Question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? William Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university.\n</Question> \n<Options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</Options>\n<Reasoning>\nStep 1: The premise states that \u201cWilliam Dickinson attended Westminster school for high school and then the University of Edinburgh.\u201d We also know that \u201cThe University of Edinburgh is a university located in the United Kingdom,\u201d so we can confirm that William Dickinson\u2019s university education took place in the UK.\nStep 2: However, the premise does not explicitly state that Westminster School is located in the UK. Although many readers might know from general knowledge that Westminster School is in London, the text itself does not provide this information.\nStep 3: Since the conclusion claims that \u201cWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university,\u201d we can confirm the university part is in the UK but have insufficient information about the high school (Westminster School).\nStep 4: Because the premise does not definitively place Westminster School in the UK, it is impossible to conclude with certainty that both schools he attended were in the UK. We therefore lack enough textual evidence to deem the conclusion strictly true.\nStep 5: There is also no premise suggesting that Westminster School is outside of the UK, so we cannot declare the conclusion false. The conclusion could be true in reality, but the text does not confirm it.\nStep 6: As a result, the statement \u201cWilliam Dickinson went to schools located in the United Kingdom for both high school and university\u201d remains unverified by the given premises and is thus uncertain.\nTherefore, the answer is (C). \n</Reasoning>\n<Answer>\nThe final answer is (C).\n</Answer>\n</EXAMPLE 3>\n\n\n\nThe following is the problem you need to solve.\n\n<Premises>\nAll people who eat salads regularly are very conscious about their health and eating habits.\nAll people who grew up in health-conscious childhood homes eat salads regularly.\nAll people who fulfill their daily nutritional intakes grew up in health-conscious childhood homes.\nAll people who disregard their physical well-being are not very conscious about their health and eating habits.\nIf people visit the gym at least once a day, then they always fulfill their daily nutritional intakes.\nTaylor either grew up in a health-conscious childhood home and disregard her physical well-being, or she did neither.\n</Premises>\n<Conclusion>\nTaylor visits the gym at least once a day.\n</Conclusion>\n<Question>\nIs the following statement true, false, or uncertain? Taylor visits the gym at least once a day.\n</Question>\n<Options>\n(A) True\n(B) False\n(C) Uncertain\n</Options>\n<Reasoning>\n"

conscious about their health and eating habits,\" we can infer that all people who grew up in health-conscious childhood homes are very conscious about their health and eating habits.\n\nStep 2: From the premise \"All people who fulfill their daily nutritional intakes grew up in health-conscious childhood homes,\" and the premise \"If people visit the gym at least once a day, then they always fulfill their daily nutritional intakes,\" we can infer that all people who visit the gym at least once a day grew up in health-conscious childhood homes.\n\nStep 3: From the premise \"Taylor either grew up in a health-conscious childhood home and disregard her physical well-being, or she did neither,\" we need to consider both possibilities:\n- If Taylor grew up in a health-conscious childhood home and disregards her physical well-being, then Taylor would eat salads regularly and be very conscious about her health and eating habits, but she would not fulfill her daily nutritional intakes, which would mean she does not visit the gym at least once a day.\n- If Taylor did not grow up in a health-conscious childhood home and does not disregard her physical well-being, then Taylor would not eat salads regularly, and thus would not be very conscious about her health and eating habits, and she would not fulfill her daily nutritional intakes, which would mean she does not visit the gym at least once a day.\n\nStep 4: We need to check if the statement \"Taylor neither grew up in a health-conscious childhood home nor does she visit the gym at least once a day\" is consistent with the given information.\n- If Taylor grew up in a health-conscious childhood home and disregarded her physical well-being, she would not visit the gym at least once a day, but the statement would be false because it states she did not grow up in a health-conscious childhood home.\n- If Taylor did not grow up in a health-conscious childhood home and did not disregard her physical well-being, she would not visit the gym at least once a day, and the statement would be true.\n\nStep 5: Since we cannot definitively determine from the given premises whether Taylor grew up in a health-conscious childhood home and disregarded her physical well-being or not, we cannot conclusively say the statement is true or false.
